testimony: Mr Chairman, if I'm not mistaken, the applicant number 4 will be called by my learned friend this morning.
Have you any objection to taking the oath - sorry, is that working, can you hear?
Have you any objection to taking the oath?
We are now continuing with this hearing, it is the 19th of August.

Thank you Mr Chairman.
	Mr Tshoane, you have an affidavit in front of you which is also before the Committee.  Do you confirm that the affidavit which is before the Committee was made by yourself and you abide by its contents?
Just before you proceed, can we just have the correct spelling?  Is it Tso or Tsho?

Thank you Mr Chairman.
	Mr Tshoane, have a look at page 2 of your affidavit - especially paragraph 5 Mr Chairman ...[intervention]
Sorry, has he confirmed the affidavit?
Yes, Mr Chairman, he confirmed it.
Mr Tshoane, can you have a look at paragraph 5 and especially line number 2 of your affidavit indicates that you were part of the unit that attacked Wesselsbron Supermarket.
And that you have read the affidavit of comrade Bhani, it has been read to you?
And that you understand it and you confirm it inasfar as it relates to the part that you took in the Wesselsbron incident?

Now, Mr Tshoane, the evidence before the Committee so far regarding your part is that you were the owner of the car that was used in the operation in Wesselsbron and that you were the driver, do you confirm that?
Do you also confirm that on the day in question you were not armed yourself, except that you were a driver?
That is correct, I was not armed.
Now, what I want is that you tell the Committee the part you took, starting from Welkom, when did you become aware of this operation, starting when you left Welkom.

I started to know about this mission when we left Welkom.  We were four, that is myself, Themba Ngesi, Zuko and Sibanda.  We left at half past seven to Wesselsbron.  When we arrived, Mr Khotle told me that we should meet Mr Bhani in Wesselsbron who would explain to us about the operation.
	When we arrived we met Mr Bhani in Wesselsbron.  He said to me I should drive the car and take all those who were taking part to town.  I did that, I took my fellow comrades to town in Wesselsbron.  When we arrived I stopped the car in front of the supermarket and they entered the supermarket, then they accomplished the mission.
No, were you present when Bhani was briefing the comrades about the operation?
That is correct, I was present.
Can you tell the Committee what he said?

Mr Bhani said to those who were responsible that he made reconnaissance about the place and then how the plan should be accomplished and then he asked as to whether they would have problems and they said no, because they know the place.  Then we left to that particular place.
Well how was the plan to be accomplished?  That is what you were asked to tell us.
They were supposed to enter there and shoot those who oppressed us.

Mr Tshoane, can you - let me put it this way, what role did he give each of you, that is Bhani, that you are going to do this, this one is going to do this and that, the other one is going to do that, can you tell the Committee in that manner?
He informed the colleagues about what should be done, then he said: "Ngesi should enter the supermarket and shoot.
Yes, what was the role going to be played by Zuko?
Zuko must also enter and shoot.
What was the role going to be played by Sibanda?
Spanda was just next to the door, he did not enter inside.  He was supposed to look for any people who would interfere with the plan.
Now can you tell the Committee what happened after they came out of the supermarket?
After they left the supermarket they entered into the car and then we drove to the location.
Yes, what did you do on your arrival at the location?
When we arrived in the township I left them there, myself and Sibanda went to Tabong, that is Welkom.
Sorry, what happened to the weapons?
We left the weapons in Wesselsbron.
Now do you know a person by the name of Moses?
Did you hear his testimony in court, when he testified in court regarding this incident?
Let me maybe remind you that he told the court that he was approached by Sibanda and he took Sibanda to you regarding transport.
And also that your refused on the first occasion.
Can you tell the Committee, were you told what was the purpose of them wanting your transport?

When they wanted transport they - I had a certain duty to do.  When he explained that he was sent by Mr Khotle, that is then that I agreed.  I remember that Mr Khotle said there will be a parcel which I was supposed to deliver to him.
It is said that Moses told the court that Sibanda, if I'm not mistaken according to the court Jugement, Sibanda told you that there is a robbery which is going to take place at Wesselsbron.
No, he did not tell me that.
And also that Moses told the court that after the incident at Wesselsbron, you told him about that but when you were still narrating what actually took place some people came and you stopped.
No, I don't know that.  Maybe it is a story which has been fabricated by the police and him.
Is there anything you want to add to your testimony to the Committee, you want to say in addition to what you have told the Committee?
What I want to explain before this Committee is that oppressors are the ones who have organised those people, that those who are going to testify in court should testify in the way they did.

Mr Tshoane, putting aside what happened in court, I'm saying regarding this incident at Wesselsbron, of you taking part in what happened, is there anything you want to add or you want to say to the Committee?
It was supposed that this work should be accomplished in whatever way, the plan which was used by those who were oppressed ...[intervention]
Now Mr Tshoane, without deferring to what we are saying, let me lead you this way.  You know that people died as a result of this incident, is there anything you want to say regarding that?

They were supposed to die because in war people die.  We were struggling for liberation and by any means people would die.  That many people would die in that kind of an incident, mainly those who oppressed our black people during the previous government.

Thank you Mr Chairman, I have nothing to say.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR MBANDAZAYO

Thank you Mr Chairman, Honourable Members.
	Sir, I just want to ask you a question related to yesterday's information given by Mr Khotle, if I pronounce it correctly.  Do you agree with the evidence or the statement of Mr Khotle yesterday, when he told the Chairperson that amongst other things the order also was to kill anything that was alive in the store, or words to that effect?  Do you agree with his testimony yesterday to this effect?
Was this your specific instructions, or what were your specific instructions regarding the supermarket?
I don't understand your question Sir.  Will you please repeat it?
I'll gladly do so.  What exactly were your instruction which you received from your commander regarding the supermarket at Wesselsbron?
The instruction I received is to drive the car, to take the participants to the place of the incident.

Before I turn to your amnesty application itself I just want to ask you another question.  Did anybody at any instance give you any orders to attack the white communities, did you get such orders from anybody?
That kind of instruction was not given to me, it was given to those who were my seniors.
You have never received such orders, am I right?  Is that what you are saying?

Well maybe you can help me.  I want to refer to your amnesty application, page 3, Mr Chairman, Honourable Members, and specifically to paragraph 11 2(b), page 3 Mr Chairperson.
	Do you have it Sir?

I just want to read what you've actually said there and maybe you can comment on it.
"Intensify the armed struggle and take it to the white communities.  The order was given by Sabelo Pama, Pasia Village, Umtata, Transkei"
What does this mean?
Can you comment on that Sir, because according to this paragraph it seems to me that you got certain orders to take the armed struggle to the white communities, isn't that correct?
But why did you deny it?  When I asked you the previous question you denied it.  Why did you deny it?
You talked about - you are not talking about the paper which is in front of me.
Do you understand my question Sir?
I specifically asked whether or not you had any instructions to attack the white communities and you said no.  According to your own application it seems ...[intervention]

But didn't your question follow on immediately after your first question, which was: "Was an order given to kill anything that was alive"?  And he agreed with that, and then you asked him about orders to attack the white community.  Wasn't his attention specifically drawn to the day in question?
I agree Mr Chairman, there can be some misunderstanding.
I understood you were asking him what instructions he got on that day.
Sir, the attack on the supermarket, can you indicate to the Committee exactly what the reason was for, your personal reason or the reason you thought to be for attacking the supermarket?
The reason for attacking the supermarket was the struggle for liberation.
Can I refer you to your amnesty application, page 2.  This is under paragraph 9 (a) 4, with the heading there reading: Nature and Particulars.  Do you see that?

Can I read this to you?
"We entered the Wesselsbron Supermarket whose owner was Chairperson of the AWB.  On entering there were five of us.  We shot all the white people who were inside indiscriminately.  We did not remove any articles from the supermarket"
Are you saying that the owner of the supermarket was the Chairperson of the AWB, is that what you are saying?
Because he was white I would say that.
Why didn't you include this testimony in your evidence in chief, that the Chairperson according to you, the shop owner at least was the Chairperson of the AWB?
He was an AWB member because he was white, because the struggle was directed against white people.
Mr Tshoane, the question was: "Why did you say he was the Chairperson of the AWB"?  If we heard you correctly you were saying: "Because he was white".  Is that correct?

Well am I white or not?  The reason why I'm asking this, I have a white skin, am I the Chairperson of the AWB?  You see your answer doesn't make sense.  Won't you reconsider and give us an answer as to why you say that individual was the Chairperson of the AWB?
At that time when we committed this incident we were directing our struggle against white people.
Yes, the question is, why do you say that the owner was the Chairperson of the AWB?
I would say that because in many instances, according to the information we gathered, gathered by members of APLA and PAC, the AWB used to assemble in that place.

Would you look at that answer of yours again in the application form.  You are saying that the owner of the supermarket was the Chairperson of the Afrikaner Resistance Movement, AWB.  The owner was heading up the party of the AWB.  There are a lot of white people in South Africa, they're not all the Chairpersons of AWB, why do you say he was the Chairperson.  Did you write it or did someone else tell you to put it in there?
Ja.  Who told you to write it?
Nobody told me, I did it myself.
Now the question is, do you have an answer as to why you say he was the leader of the AWB in that area?
According to the information we gathered he was the one who appeared to be the Chairperson of the AWB.
You say the information you gathered, "we gathered".  Did you get that information yourself, and from whom did you get it?
I was informed by our regional commander who is Mr Khotle.
Did Mr Khotle tell you that this owner was the Chairperson of the AWB?  Is that your answer?
Yes, that is the person who said so.
You heard his evidence didn't you?

And you didn't say it only once in your application.  If you look at paragraph 10(a) at the bottom of the same page, you again say that
"The political objective was to carry forward the armed struggle waged by the PAC/APLA at the time.  As the supermarket was owned by the local Chairperson of the AWB and frequented by AWB members"
Yes, I see it Sir.
So you were giving this as the main political reason for the attack on this place?
When did Mr Khotle tell you this?
He told me on Friday, let me say, ja, that is Friday.
Was that the day of the attack?
When was it, when was the attack?
It was on the night of the 3rd of July 1993.
So this was the day before the attack he told you this?
It was on a Friday before the Saturday, a week before.  It was on a Friday of the week before the week of the attack.
So a week before you were told that this supermarket was owned by the Chairperson of the AWB?
And in what connection were you told this?
We were sitting down discussing the issues of the organisation.
And how did the issues of the organisation cover the ownership of the supermarket?
He associated this statement together with the investigations he made.
Those investigations were in regard to the supermarket.
His reconnaissance with a view to attacking the supermarket, were those the investigations?
No, it was the information he gathered, that the AWB used to frequent the supermarket.

I still don't see why you should be discussing this supermarket with him, that the AWB frequented it.  You've told me it was in connection with the investigation he made about the supermarket, what investigation did he make?
About the AWB who used to frequent the supermarket.
It was in regard to the movement of the people who used to frequent the supermarket.
When was this on the Friday?
It was the Friday of the week before, the week of the incident.
In the morning or the evening?
So at 11a.m. on the Friday morning before the attack, a week before, he told you about the investigations he had done at the supermarket, about the people frequenting it?
Did he then discuss with you that the supermarket would be a target?
Did he tell you that it was a possible target?
Can you tell us - can you then try to explain to us what he discussed with you, why did he talk about the supermarket?
He was talking about the AWB who used to frequent this place.
But why should he bother to talk about the AWB frequenting a supermarket if it was of no interest to you?
I knew that we were fighting these people.
Did you know that the AWB was also fighting the government, that they were also planting bombs?
They were not fighting the apartheid government, they were fighting the Africans.

Sir, can I take you to page 3 of your application?
	Mr Chairperson, it's under paragraph 10, 10(d), page 3.
	Do you have that Sir?  It is under the heading: "If so, explain the nature and extent of such benefits", do you see that?

I just want to read that for you and ask you for your comment.
"Politically and militarily as one AWB members died and also one white policeman was killed"
Where did you get this information from?
I got it from the newspapers.
Sir, since when were you a member of APLA and where were you trained?
I've never been a member of the AWB.
I was trained inside the country in Transkei.
I was a member of the task force.

Sir, what will your comment be if I tell you that according to the police investigation, and at least a police investigating officer who is present here and if needs be he will come and testify, that you were never a member of APLA but you were only recruited by this gang or group because they needed your transportation and your vehicle?  What will your comment be to that?
I dispute that at all because I'm a member of the, I'm an African.  I was trained with the members of the PAC to engage in the political struggle.
Can you tell the Committee, what was taken from the shop, was anything taken from the shop?
Who took the money and how was it taken, was it taken in bags or what?  What happened to the money?
Yes, it was in the bags in our pockets.
And who removed the money from the shop, did all of you do it or was there a specific individual tasked to do it?
It was taken by those who were inside the shop.
You say the money was in your pockets, did you have money in your pockets?
How do you know the money was in the pockets of others?
According to the evidence given by Ngesi.

I'm not talking evidence Mr Tshoane, we want you to talk about what you know.  We heard what Mr Ngesi said.  Did you know that money was put in his pocket?  Did you hear from his evidence now or did you know it before?
Did you not know that before he gave evidence?
No, I did not know before.
So you didn't know that money was taken until you heard Mr Ngesi's evidence, is that what you're telling us?
Was it the first time here that you heard that money was taken, when Mr Ngesi gave evidence?
So they didn't tell you at the time, after you drove them away after the shooting, that money was taken?
And you got no money from them for driving them there?
You were tried for this offence weren't you?  You've been asked about what was said at the trial.
Wasn't evidence led about the money that was stolen at the trial?
Well how could you say a minute ago to my colleague here, that you heard about money here for the first time?  That was a lie wasn't it, you heard about it at the trial.
Yes, even here.  I did not see money at all.
You weren't asked about seeing money, you were asked if you heard about money.

But why did you tell my colleague here that you didn't here about it until you heard the evidence here.  He asked you several times to make it quite clear and you said you didn't know about the money before, you heard about the money here.
This thing happened a long time ago, it's five years and I forget some of the things.

Are you now suggesting that you forgot that you were charged with robbery and convicted of robbery which involved the stealing of R4 000, and that evidence was led about this at your trial?  Are you seriously suggesting to us that you forgot this?
According to them I was charged with robbery although I did not take part in robbery.  We went there to take money which will help to enhance the struggle for liberation.
So you now say you know you went there to take money?

And yet you've just a minute ago said you've forgotten about the money because it happened a long time ago.
	That is what he said, isn't it?
May you please repeat your question.
Can you explain why, when you've now just told me you went there to get money for the liberation?
So how could you say before that: "It happened a long time ago, I forgot about the money"?  No explanation, carry on.

May I just take this further please Chair.  There may be some misunderstanding.  My initial question related to the money being carried in their pockets, you had no knowledge of that, that is what you told me, is that correct?
And if I understood you correctly, you were waiting outside in the car, you didn't know that they took money, is that correct?
And your evidence was that the instructions given by Bhani to Ngesi and to Zuko was only to shoot?
He gave no instructions that money was to be taken at that stage?
Money was part of the mission.
How did you know that?  We know it was part of the mission, from their evidence, my question is, did you know it then?
I did not know anything at that time.

But this is the point Mr Tshoane, I want you to give evidence only on what you know or knew at the time, don't give us the evidence that we can get from the other people.  We want your story and we want your full disclosure of what you know.
	You in your evidence in chief said that the instructions while you were driving, the briefing, was to Ngesi to shoot, only instruction, to Zuko, to shoot, only instruction, you now said there was no instruction at the time that you heard of that money was to be taken, is that correct?
The instruction given was to shoot.
There was no instruction at that time that you heard of, that money was to be taken, is that correct?
The instruction given was to shoot.
And at the time of the incident you had no knowledge of money, of any money, is that what you're telling us?
You did not know that they had money in their pockets?
I did not see any money and I didn't know about it.
And when you dropped them at the location, as you gave evidence, and you and Sibanda continued, you had no knowledge of any money.
Yes, I did not know anything about money.
Mr Tshoane, when you were told to drive the others, what were you told was the purpose of going to that supermarket?
The objective of going to that supermarket was going to fight those who were oppressing us in our land.
So you were driving the others to go and fight, was that the purpose of driving the others to the supermarket?
My reason for driving them to the supermarket was for going to fight.
That is only shoot the people you would find in the supermarket, do I hear you correctly?
Because we were involved in the armed struggle our reason was to shoot them and to take money.  That is how we were operating then.
So did you know the purpose was to shoot them and to take money?
So did you expect the others to have taken money or didn't you expect them to have taken money, when they left the supermarket, after the shooting?
Did you expect them to have done so?  You have told us a minute ago that the purpose was to go there to shoot people and to take money, did you expect them to do that?
That is how we were operating then.  That is how we were operating during that time of oppression.
So that it what you expected, for them to shoot and to take money?
Had you taken part in other such operations?
But you knew that that is how they operated? - "That is how we operated at the time"
My main function there was just to drive them that time.

You have just told me that you knew, or you told the Committee, that to shoot and take money was how you operated during this time, the period of your oppression.  Do you remember telling us that a minute or two ago?
How did you know, you'd never been on an operation before, how did you know that this is how they operated?
My superiors told me that way.
Did he tell you that on this occasion?
He told me many times.  He told me about many things that were happening in our organisation.

Sir, I in my possession a statement which you made to the police, which I gladly hand in the moment I'm able to make copies.
	According to the statement, your warning statement to the police ...[intervention]
Mr Chairman, I think it will be unfair to put that statement without ourselves also not having an insight to that statement, taken too that we have not been put in possession of that statement.
So he's being cross-examined on it, you'll see it.  I gather Mr Steenkamp has not seen it before now.
Mr Chairman, my objection is that also I think even before that we are supposed to be given such information.
I've asked Mr Steenkamp yesterday.  I told him that he must give us everything that is in his possession which he is going to use here.  I've told him - he was here, I told him ...[intervention]
How long do you require to read this statement?  Five minutes?
Well Mr Chairman, it definitely won't be long.  It depends, if it's one page it could be two minutes Mr Chairman.
Pass it to him.  How long is it Mr Steenkamp?
Sir, it took me five minutes to read.  It's about 7 or 8 pages.

Very well, we'll take the short adjournment now and then we can continue uninterrupted I hope.

Yes, Mr Chairman, I had an opportunity to go through it with my client, thank you Mr Chairman.
Thank you for your indulgence Mr Chairman, Honourable Members.  If I may just ask a few questions on this statement, if you would allow me.

Thank you Mr Chairman.
	Sir, you had the opportunity to read and go through this statement, am I right?
The speaker's mike is not on.

I did this statement under duress.  I was beaten, I was assaulted before I made this statement.
So, can you just explain to us where the police got this information from, the detailed information about the incident?
They got this information from the informer.
And who was this person, do you know?
Please help me if I'm wrong, this statement was never contested in the Supreme Court in the way you're doing now, am I right?

So why didn't you contest this statement in the Supreme Court when you had the opportunity to do so?  Why didn't you tell the learned Judge, the Presiding Officer, that you were actually assaulted, and that this information came from the informer?
I tried to explain in court but they did not listen to me, they dismissed my statement.

Are you saying that you tried to explain at your trial that you had been assaulted before you made this statement and accordingly it shouldn't be admissible but they just dismissed your statement, paid no regard to it?
That is what I'm saying Chairperson.
Are you saying that the facts in this statement is not true?
Can you tell us what specifically is not true in this statement?
What was the car that you drove with?  What make and model?
Was it a bakkie or a delivery van or what was it?
Are you saying in the statement that you drove with a van or are you describing a different car?  Is that car correct, the reference to the car in the statement?
That is correct, that is true, I was driving a 1400 Datsun van.
You referred to Danny going with you?
Now why do you say the statement in total is incorrect.

Police asked me about what they already know because if you look on the date, I was arrested on the 19th, then on the 3rd and then they started assaulting me on the 4th.  They forced me to make this statement.
Let's except that for the moment, that they forced you, the question is, what is incorrect in this statement, can you tell us what is not true?  What in the statement is not true?
Did you not go in the car that you described here?  Were you describing a different car?
I was explaining about the same car which I was driving and the police knew that I was driving the same car.
Did you stop, as you say in your statement, in front of the supermarket?
Did you hear gunshots while you were waiting in the car?
Did you leave the scene when they came out, dropped them off, as you say here?
Now what is not correct?  What in your statement is untrue, can you point out anything that you said in your statement that is not true?
All those things which were said by Leglogiso, told them, they forced me to agree with.
To make an example - I didn't want to explain to them what happened.  If I were to tell them the truth I would be killed.
But make an example of what was not true.
Well did you drive to the supermarket or did Danny?
So it's not true to say Danny drove, as you say in the statement, that was not true?
And did Danny move the car after the shooting to another parking place?
No, I was the one who was driving.
Did you go to a corrugated-iron house?
Is that where the guns were collected?
That is correct, that is where I left the guns.
Were the guns collected there before?
Yes, we collected the guns there.
So the guns weren't brought from Welkom or anything?
We brought three guns from Welkom.
Well how did they get to the corrugated-iron house, you said you collected them from there?
We took them there when we returned from the supermarket.
Before you went to the supermarket, did you collect guns?
We had three guns and then we took two guns from the corrugated-iron house.
So then you had five guns?
Why did you take five guns?
They were going to be used by the people who were supposed to use them.
Were there five people supposed to be using guns?
May you please repeat your question Sir?
You say the five guns were supposed to be used by the people who were participating.  Now the question is, were there five people?
The other gun was left in the car.
So did four people take guns and move in?
That Zuko, Ngesi, Bhani and Khotle.
Did Mr Khotle also go into the shop, into the supermarket?
This is important, surely you know?  Did Mr Khotle travel with you to the supermarket?
I don't remember Sir, I'm now confused, I don't remember.

You told us now that four people took guns and went into the shop.  You named them freely, you said it was Zuko, Ngesi, Bhani and Khotle.
	Can someone please attend to the message here from the interpreters?
	Mr Tshoane, you said that five guns were taken in the van.
You say five guns were taken in the van?
I don't remember well what exactly happened, it is after a long time.
Let me take you back.  You said that you had three guns, you went to this corrugated-iron house and you took two more guns, so you then had five guns, is that correct?
You said the five guns were to be used by the people who would be participating in this exercise, is that correct?
Then you said only four people took guns, one gun was left in the van, is that correct?
Now who were the four people?
That is Ngesi, Zuko and Bhani and Sibande.
And Khotle, did he stay in the car?
Well how did you come to say a few minutes ago that he was one of the people who took a gun?
I said before that I was confused.
No, you didn't, you said you were confused after you were asked about Mr Khotle.
I made a mistake by saying somebody who was not present.
Did you know Zuko, Ngesi and Bhani from before or did you meet them then?
How many of you travelled to the supermarket?
In your statement to the police you said all five the persons got out of the car, now who were: "all five"?

As I've already explained about the statement, I made that statement under pressure because they forced me to make that statement.  They were leading me with the information because they knew, therefore I had to write what they knew or what they wanted me to write because I did not have any option, I had to do that.
Did you tell them that there were not five people but yourself, Sibande and three others?  Did you tell them that?

I told them they way I did because they were assaulting me and they were leading me with the information so I had to verify what they told me.  They took me to the police station to make a confession statement, then they said I should make this statement.
So you did not offer any information to them, you didn't tell them anything?
Yes, they told me to write what is in the statement because I didn't co-operate with them.
And if I heard you correctly you said to Mr Steenkamp that this was not raised in your defence at the court case?
The question was, why didn't you tell them at the court case that this statement was made, that you were led with this statement, that you didn't co-operate at all?
I briefed my lawyer about that.
Did you give evidence at your trial?
Were you questioned about this statement?
I disputed the statement in court.
Were you questioned about it when you gave evidence?
Yes.  I resisted and I disputed, that this is a statement made by the police whilst they were assaulting me.
Did the police tell you to put in your statement that Danny drove the vehicle?
I told them because they were assaulting me, I didn't have any other option.
The question was, did the police tell you to say that?
Yes, they were leading me with that information because they knew everything about me.
Well if they knew everything about you, does that mean Danny did drive the motorcar?
They were assaulting me, I didn't have any other option.  I ended up by saying whatever they say I would agree with them.
Yes, but you've just said: "The police were leading me with information because they knew all about me".  That would imply that the information they were leading you with was correct.
It was not true because it was received from the third person, not from me.
So you say the police did tell you that?
Did you have a driver's licence at that time?
So when you said that you refused to drive because you did not have a driver's licence and you told that Danny should drive, was that true or was that not true?
That was not correct, that was not true.  I wanted them to leave because what they were saying came from the informer.  ...[no English translation]  Moses Leglogiso.
Did Moses know that you did not have a driver's licence?
